admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia

abstracts.cdata!:
Achievement of the project objectives is
            judged to be satisfactory. This project was designed as an
            ancillary project, intended to facilitate implementation of
            the Enterprise and Financial Sector Adjustment Loan (EFSAL),
            and therefore should be viewed in that context. To some
            extent, delays in implementing policy reforms of the EFSAL,
            particularly in the energy sector, have diminished the
            impact of some of the preparatory activities financed under
            the TAL. Project sustainability, where applicable, is
            considered likely: policy dialogue continues and it appears
            that the new Government is committed to continuing reforms
            in order for Croatia to become a full-fledged market
            economy. World Bank performance in all aspects of the
            project cycle was satisfactory while the performance of the
            Borrower's implementing agencies was, overall,
            satisfactory. Lessons learned include the following: The
            flexibility in TAL's design allowed project
            implementation to continue both when technical assistance
            priorities changed and when alternative financing was found.
            The project management structure was adapted specifically to
            support the government's large reform program. The fact
            that several implementing agencies were each given
            responsibility for executing their own components avoided
            creation of a bottleneck which would have appeared had all
            procurement gone through the Project Implementation Unit
            that was managing a second Bank-financed project at the same time.
